repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Pilot Private Irrigation
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. Interesting lessons
            suggest the following. The approach developed by the project
            has shown that rural private entrepreneurs can efficiently
            replace public services, for advisory services or equipment
            dissemination. However, this does not happen all of a
            sudden, rather requires targeted supports: training, both on
            technical aspects and entrepreneurship skills; economic
            organization of artisans, and, the institutional
            organization of distribution networks. Experience shows the
            objective of entrepreneurial development should be
            reinforced in further operations. Moreover, the project
            demonstrates that small scale irrigation can be a profitable
            activity, and an efficient tool to increasing
            producers' incomes. To this end, public resources
            should not only target large irrigation schemes, but promote
            the development of private networks for the dissemination of
            such technologies and techniques. Further lessons show how a
            private institution may indeed be competent and efficient in
            implementing a project using public financing resources,
            able to progress and improve its institutional capacity, and
            to avoid managing all activities by itself, rather the
            contrary, delegating execution to subsidiary institutions
            and private firms under contractual arrangements.

5084366.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Financial and private sector development,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Pilot Private Irrigation
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pilot Private Irrigation Development
            Project seeks to test and evaluate an approach for the
            provision of demand-driven support services necessary to
            develop an efficient, sustainable small irrigation
            sub-sector in Burkina Faso. There are four project
            components. 1) The first component will finance the project
            technical executing agency and its capacity building. 2) The
            second component will promote new technologies through
            on-farm and off-farm support services including technical
            feasibility studies for micro irrigation and related
            investments. This component focuses on providing target
            beneficiaries (small irrigation farmers, private operators
            involved in the marketing and processing of irrigation
            products, and providers of farm inputs and services to
            irrigation activities) support services aimed at increasing
            their incomes and employment. 3) The third component will
            help the target beneficiaries establish a record in the
            formal credit system, thereby gaining access in the future
            to the formal banking sector. 4) The fourth component will
            support the establishment of a strong monitoring and
            evaluation capacity. 5) The fifth component will set up a
            financial coordination unit, which is responsible for the
            financial management of the project.
